p: Chi-Hyuck Jun was born in Seoul, Korea in 1954. He received a B.S. (1977) in mineral and petroleum engineering from Seoul National University, an M.S. (1979) in industrial engineering from KAIST, and a Ph.D. (1986) in operations research from University of California, Berkeley. Since 1987, he has been with the department of industrial and management engineering, POSTECH; and he is now a professor, and the department head. He is interested in reliability and quality analysis, and data mining techniques. He is a member of IEEE, INFORMS, and ASQ.

authors.affiliation: Nat. Core Res. Center for Syst. Bio-Dynamics, Pohang Univ. of Sci. & Technol., Kyungbuk, South Korea
authors.name: Chi-Hyuck Jun

p: S. Balamurali received his M. Sc., and Ph. D. degrees in Statistics from Bharathiar University, India. He is presently working as a Research Professor in the Division of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, POSTECH. His research interests include statistical process control, and acceptance sampling. His recent publications have appeared in the engineering, and applied statistics journals.

authors.affiliation: Nat. Core Res. Center for Syst. Bio-Dynamics, Pohang Univ. of Sci. & Technol., Kyungbuk, South Korea
authors.name: S. Balamurali

p: Sang-Ho Lee was born in Samcheok, Korea in 1980. He Received a B.S. (2004) in industrial engineering from POSTECH. He is now a Ph. D. student in the Department of Industrial and Management Engineering at POSTECH. His interests are in data mining, and applied statistics.

authors.affiliation: Nat. Core Res. Center for Syst. Bio-Dynamics, Pohang Univ. of Sci. & Technol., Kyungbuk, South Korea
authors.name: Sang-Ho Lee

details.abstract: Sudden death testing can be utilized for deciding upon the lot acceptance of manufactured parts. Variables single, and double sampling plans are proposed for the lot acceptance of parts whose life follows a Weibull distribution with known shape parameter. The proposed plans are different from the existing ones in that the lot acceptance criteria do not depend on the estimated scale parameter. Design parameters of both sampling plans are determined by using the usual two-point approach. The number of groups is determined independently of the group size, and even independently of the shape parameter. Also, the double sampling plan can reduce the average number of groups required. The effects of mis-specification of the shape parameter on the probability of accepting the lots under the single sampling plan are analyzed & discussed.
details.formulaStrippedArticleTitle: Variables sampling plans for Weibull distributed lifetimes under sudden death testing

citations.title: Variables sampling plans for Weibull distributed lifetimes under sudden death testing

context.text: The total number of specimens to be evaluated \$n\$ is divided into equal-sized groups according to the number of available experimental testers, for example [1], [2].
Particularly, when the number of test positions is limited, sudden death testing is preferred [1].

references.title: The modified sudden death test: planning life tests with a limited number of test positions
references.text: F. G. Pascual, W. Q. Meeker, "The modified sudden death test: planning life tests with a limited number of test positions", Journal of Testing and Evaluation, vol. 26, no. 5, pp. 434-443, 1998.

context.text: The total number of specimens to be evaluated \$n\$ is divided into equal-sized groups according to the number of available experimental testers, for example [1], [2].

references.title: Monte Carlo Simulation of Sudden Death Bearing Testing
references.text: B. L. Vlcek, R. C. Hendricks, E. V. Zaretsky, Monte Carlo Simulation of Sudden Death Bearing Testing, 2003, NASA.

context.text: Balasooriya [3] first considers reliability sampling plans under the sudden death testing for the two parameter exponential distribution although the terminology ‘sudden death’ was not mentioned.
The proposed plans are different from those in [3] in that the lot acceptance criteria in [3] depend on the estimated distribution parameters, while ours do not.
So we may use the results in [3] for the exponential distribution.

references.title: Failure-censored reliability sampling plans for the exponential distribution
references.text: U. Balasooriya, "Failure-censored reliability sampling plans for the exponential distribution", Journal of Statistical Computation and Simulation, vol. 52, no. 4, pp. 337-349, 1995.

links.abstract: When the distribution of lifetimes is 2-parameter exponential, Balasooriya (1995) provided a failure-censored reliability sampling plan to save test time. This paper extends the Balasooriya sampling plan to the Weibull distribution and provides a limited failure-censored reliability sampling plan (LFCR) to do life testing when test facilities are scarce. The s-expected test time of the LFCR is computed, and the optimal stopping rule of LFCR corresponding to the shortest test time is established....

context.text: [4] called this type of test a ‘limited failure-censored life test,’ and analyzed the expected test time.

references.title: Limited failure-censored life test for the Weibull distribution
references.text: J.-W. Wu, T.-R. Tsai, L.-Y. Ouyang, "Limited failure-censored life test for the Weibull distribution", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 50, no. 1, pp. 107-111, 2001.

context.text: Reliability sampling plans for the Weibull distribution under a type-II censoring scheme are proposed in [5], [6].

As in Fertig & Mann [5], the probability of acceptance should be \$1-\alpha\$ (\$\alpha\$ is called producer's risk) at the acceptable reliability level \$p_{0}\$, and the probability of acceptance should be \$\beta\$ (this is called consumer's risk) at the lot tolerance reliability level \$p_{1}\$.

references.title: Life-test sampling plans for two-parameter Weibull populations
references.text: K. W. Fertig, N. R. Mann, "Life-test sampling plans for two-parameter Weibull populations", Technometrics, vol. 22, no. 2, pp. 165-177, 1980.

context.text: Reliability sampling plans for the Weibull distribution under a type-II censoring scheme are proposed in [5], [6].

references.title: Failure-censored variables-sampling plans for lognormal and Weibull distributions
references.text: H. Schneider, "Failure-censored variables-sampling plans for lognormal and Weibull distributions", Technometrics, vol. 31, no. 2, pp. 199-206, 1989.

context.text: A different plan for the Weibull distribution having a known shape parameter is proposed in [7] using a cost model under some warranty policy.

references.title: A Bayesian life test sampling plan for products with Weibull lifetime distribution sold under warranty
references.text: Y. I. Kwon, "A Bayesian life test sampling plan for products with Weibull lifetime distribution sold under warranty", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 53, no. 1, pp. 61-66, 1996.

context.text: Lam [8] considers the sampling plan for the exponential distribution under a type-I censoring using a Bayesian approach.

references.title: Bayesian variable sampling plans for the exponential distribution with type I censoring
references.text: Y. Lam, "Bayesian variable sampling plans for the exponential distribution with type I censoring", The Annals of Statistics, vol. 22, no. 2, pp. 696-711, 1994.

context.text: Type-I censoring can be generalized to random censoring, and some plans are developed for the exponential distribution [9], [10].

references.title: Bayesian variable sampling plans for the exponential distribution with uniformly distributed random censoring
references.text: Y. Lam, S. T. B. Choy, "Bayesian variable sampling plans for the exponential distribution with uniformly distributed random censoring", Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference, vol. 47, no. 3, pp. 277-293, 1995.

context.text: Type-I censoring can be generalized to random censoring, and some plans are developed for the exponential distribution [9], [10].

references.title: Optimal Bayesian sampling acceptance plan with random censoring
references.text: J. Chen, S. T. B. Choy, K.-H. Li, "Optimal Bayesian sampling acceptance plan with random censoring", European Journal of Operational Research, vol. 155, no. 3, pp. 683-694, 2004.

context.text: A sampling plan for the Weibull distribution is also available under a mixture of type-I & type-II censoring schemes [11].

references.title: Designing acceptance sampling schemes for life testing with mixed censoring
references.text: J. Chen, W. Chou, H. Wu, H. Zhou, "Designing acceptance sampling schemes for life testing with mixed censoring", Naval Research Logistics, vol. 51, no. 4, pp. 597-612, 2004.

links.abstract: For many high reliability products where very few items are expected to fail during the test period, testing under normal conditions is not feasible. Further, the requirement for high reliability increases the need for test procedures which yield valuable degradation and other useful information for improving product reliability. Thus in some manufacturing and other experiments, various types of failure censored and accelerated life tests are commonly employed for life testing. In this paper we ...

context.text: Balasooriya & Low [12] propose a plan for the Weibull distribution under a type-I progressive censoring scheme by considering multiple failure modes.

references.title: Competing causes of failure and reliability tests for Weibull lifetimes under type I progressive censoring
references.text: U. Balasooriya, C.-K. Low, "Competing causes of failure and reliability tests for Weibull lifetimes under type I progressive censoring", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 53, no. 1, pp. 29-36, 2004.

context.text: The sampling plans for the Weibull distribution under a type-II progressive censoring scheme are considered by many authors [13]–[15].

references.title: Progressively censored reliability sampling plans for the Weibull distribution
references.text: U. Balasooriya, S. L. C. Saw, V. Gadag, "Progressively censored reliability sampling plans for the Weibull distribution", Technometrics, vol. 42, no. 2, pp. 160-167, 2000.

context.text: The sampling plans for the Weibull distribution under a type-II progressive censoring scheme are considered by many authors [13]–[14][15].

references.title: Reliability sampling plans for the Weibull distribution under type II progressive censoring with binomial removals
references.text: S.-K. Tse, C. Yang, "Reliability sampling plans for the Weibull distribution under type II progressive censoring with binomial removals", Journal of Applied Statistics, vol. 30, no. 6, pp. 709-718, 2003.

context.text: The sampling plans for the Weibull distribution under a type-II progressive censoring scheme are considered by many authors [13]–[15].

references.title: Optimal progressive censoring plans for the Weibull distribution
references.text: H. K. T. Ng, P. S. Chan, N. Balakrishnan, "Optimal progressive censoring plans for the Weibull distribution", Technometrics, vol. 46, no. 4, pp. 470-481, 2004.

context.text: Similar plans under type-II progressive censoring for the two-parameter exponential distribution, and for the lognormal distribution, are available in [16], and [17], respectively.

references.title: Reliability sampling plans for the two-parameter exponential distribution under progressive censoring
references.text: U. Balasooriya, S. L. C. Saw, "Reliability sampling plans for the two-parameter exponential distribution under progressive censoring", Journal of Applied Statistics, vol. 25, no. 5, pp. 707-714, 1998.

links.abstract: This paper presents reliability sampling plans for the lognormal distribution based on progressively censored samples. In constructing these sampling plans, large-sample approximations to the best linear unbiased estimators of the location and scale parameters are used. For some selected progressive censoring schemes, reliability sampling plans are tabulated for p/sub /spl alpha// and p/sub /spl beta// to match MIL-STD-105. While in general, variable-sampling plans require smaller sample size wh...

context.text: Similar plans under type-II progressive censoring for the two-parameter exponential distribution, and for the lognormal distribution, are available in [16], and [17], respectively.

references.title: Reliability sampling plans for lognormal distribution, based on progressively-censored samples
references.text: U. Balasooriya, N. Balakrishnan, "Reliability sampling plans for lognormal distribution based on progressively-censored samples", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 49, no. 2, pp. 199-203, 2000.

context.text: Most decision rules regarding lot acceptance are based on the one in Lieberman & Resnikoff [18].

references.title: Sampling plans for inspection by variables
references.text: G. J. Lieberman, G. J. Resnikoff, "Sampling plans for inspection by variables", Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 50, pp. 457-516, 1955.

links.abstract: The likelihood equations based on a progressively Type-II censored sample from a Gaussian distribution do not provide explicit solutions in any situation except the complete sample case. This paper examines numerically the bias and mean square error of the MLE, and demonstrates that the probability coverages of the pivotal quantities (for location and scale parameters) based on asymptotic s-normality are unsatisfactory, and particularly so when the effective sample size is small. Therefore, this...

context.text: See for example [19], [20].

references.title: Point and interval estimation for Gaussian distribution, based on progressively type-II censored samples
references.text: N. Balakrishnan, N. Kannan, C. T. Lin, H. K. T. Ng, "Point and interval estimation for Gaussian distribution based on progressively type-II censored samples", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 52, no. 1, pp. 90-95, 2003.

links.abstract: Based on progressively Type-II censored samples, the maximum likelihood, and Bayes estimators for some lifetime parameters (reliability, and hazard functions), as well as the parameters of the Burr-XII model, are derived. The Bayes estimators are obtained using both the symmetric (Squared Error, SE) loss function, and asymmetric (LINEX, and General Entropy, GE) loss functions. This was done with respect to the conjugate prior for the one shape parameter, and discrete prior for the other paramete...

context.text: See for example [19], [20].

references.title: Estimation of parameters of life from progressively censored data using Burr-XII model
references.text: A. A. Soliman, "Estimation of parameters of life from progressively censored data using Burr-XII model", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 54, no. 1, pp. 34-42, 2005.

links.abstract: The Weibull distribution indexed by scale and shape parameters is generally used as a distribution of lifetime. In determining whether or not a production lot is accepted, one wants the most effective sample size and the acceptance criterion for the specified producer and consumer risks. (/spl mu//sub 0/ /spl equiv/ acceptable MTTF; /spl mu//sub 1/ /spl equiv/ rejectable MTTF). Decide on the most effective reliability test satisfying both constraints: Pr{reject a lot | MTTF = /spl mu//sub 0/} /s...

context.text: In fact, the above sampling plan under sudden death testing can be reduced to a single sampling plan under complete testing as in Hisada & Arizino [21] when the shape parameter is known.

references.title: Reliability tests for Weibull distribution with varying shape-parameter, based on complete data
references.text: K. Hisada, I. Arizino, "Reliability tests for Weibull distribution with varying shape-parameter based on complete data", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 51, no. 3, pp. 331-336, 2002.

context.text: Alternatively, we determine these parameters to minimize the average number of groups required at \$p_{0}\$, which is analogous to minimizing the average sample number in a usual double sampling plan (See [22]).

references.title: Two-point double variables sampling plan
references.text: D. J. Sommers, "Two-point double variables sampling plan", Journal of Quality Technology, vol. 13, no. 1, pp. 25-30, 1981.

references.text: J. B. Keats, P. C. Nahar, K. M. Korbell, "A study of the effect of mis-specification of the Weibull shape parameter on confidence bounds based on the Weibull-exponential transformation", Quality and Reliability Engineering International, vol. 16, pp. 27-31, 2000.

references.text: M. Xie, Z. Yang, O. Gaudoin, "More on the mis-specification of the shape parameter with Weibull-to-exponential transformation", Quality and Reliability Engineering International, vol. 16, pp. 281-290, 2000.
